entry.et: Middle English, adverb & preposition, from Old English beforan, from be- + foran before, from fore

def.dt: :in advance :ahead marching on before
:at an earlier time :previously the night before knew her from before
:forward of :in front of stood before the fire
:in the presence of speaking before the conference
:under the jurisdiction or consideration of the case before the court
:at the disposal of the great sums placed before him
:in store for got the whole summer before you
:preceding in time :earlier than just before noon
:in a higher or more important position than put quantity before quality
:earlier than the time that call me before you go
:sooner or quicker than I'll be done before you know it
:so that … do not get out of there before you get dirty
:until the time that miles to go before I sleep Robert Frost
:or else … not must be convicted before he can be removed from office
:or else get out of here before I call a cop
:rather or sooner than would starve before he'd steal
:in the near future :soon

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English mæst; akin to Old High German mast mast, Latin malus

def.dt: :a long pole or spar rising from the keel or deck of a ship and supporting the yards, booms, and rigging
:a slender vertical or nearly vertical structure (as an upright post in various cranes)
:a disciplinary proceeding at which the commanding officer of a naval unit hears and disposes of cases against enlisted men called also captain's mast
:forward of the foremast
:as a common sailor

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English; akin to Old High German wint wind, Latin ventus, Greek aēnai to blow, Sanskrit vāti it blows

def.dt: :a natural movement of air of any velocity
:the earth's air or the gas surrounding a planet in natural motion horizontally
:an artificially produced movement of air
:solar wind stellar wind
:a destructive force or influence
:a force or agency that carries along or influences :tendency trend withstood the winds of popular opinion Felix Frankfurter
:breath 4a
:breath 2a
:the pit of the stomach :solar plexus
:gas generated in the stomach or the intestines pass wind
:compressed air or gas
:air
:something that is insubstantial: as
:mere talk :idle words
:nothing nothingness
:vain self-satisfaction
:air carrying a scent (as of a hunter or game)
:slight information especially about something secret :intimation got wind of the plan
:musical wind instruments especially as distinguished from strings and percussion
:players of wind instruments
:a direction from which the wind may blow :a point of the compass
:one of the cardinal points
:the direction from which the wind is blowing
:in the same direction as the main force of the wind
:as nearly as possible against the main force of the wind
:to be to windward of
:to be on the scent of
:to have a superior position to
:about to happen :astir afoot change is in the wind
:close to the wind
:close to a point of danger :near the permissible limit
:away from the direction from which the wind is blowing
:toward the direction from which the wind is blowing
:aside away threw caution to the wind
:to leeward
:in a place protected from the wind :under the lee
